The ways in which we have prioritized state-delivered education should spur reflection on the ability of civil society to offer all children broader communities of support and opportunity. #SchoolChoice

American public education is failing too many children, and schools alone cannot be expected to remedy differences stemming from family, neighborhood, and social environments. #EdReform #EdPolicy #SchoolChoiceWeek
NEW: Policymakers should consider the effects of COVID-related closures on domestic violence rates and look for ways to mitigate the unintended consequences.
Even before any potential impact from coronavirus, marriage rates hit an all-time low in the United States. Read more 👇🏼

Public education aspired to be the common ground on which sectarianism could be put aside to focus on values we all share. This model is breaking down, evidenced by parents frustrated at their inability to influence the content or context of their child’s educational experience.

Rebalancing the amount of responsibility schools have, by leveraging the resources and support of broader communities, will make it easier for teachers to teach, for students to learn, and for communities to thrive.

Schools today are asked to do a lot of the heavy lifting that was once done by civil society and family. Teachers are asked to be instructors, advisors, life coaches, guidance counselors, discipline enforcers, moral leaders, and therapists.

Happy #SchoolChoiceWeek from the JEC! 
The Social Capital Project sees improving the effectiveness of investments in youth and young adults as a key to strengthening civil society. Education pluralism is key to this effort. Learn more in our recent paper ↓
